March 17, 1985: Fiction
IF TOMORROW COMES, by Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $17.95.) A young woman
destroys the crime lords who got her an undeserved prison term.
FAMILY ALBUM, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $16.95.) A married couple with five
children cope with the crises of contemporary America.
GLITZ, by Elmore Leonard. (Arbor House, $14.95.) The escapades, romantic and
melodramatic, of a cop on the lam after a murder in Miami.
THINNER, by Richard Bachman. (NAL Books, $12.95.) In this novel by Stephen
King, a young lawyer finds his body mysteriously wasting away.
THE FINISHING SCHOOL, by Gail Godwin. (Viking, $16.95.) A young girl's
relationship with an extraordinary older woman unintentionally leads to her
mentor's downfall.
SEE YOU LATER ALLIGATOR, by William F. Buckley Jr. (Doubleday, $15.95.)
John F. Kennedy sends Blackford Oakes to Havana on the eve of the missile
crisis.
THE SICILIAN, by Mario Puzo. (Linden Press/ Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) A
fictionalized life of Salvatore Giuliano, the Sicilian bandit hero of the 1940's.
MEXICO SET, by Len Deighton. (Knopf, $16.95.) The espionage game begun in
''Berlin Game'' resumes in Mexico City.
MINDBEND, by Robin Cook. (Putnam, $15.95.) A drug company gains control of
the medical profession.
MOSCOW RULES, by Robert Moss. (Villard Books, $16.95.) A Soviet citizen,
angry at conditions behind the Iron Curtain, plots a new revolution.
THE TALISMAN, by Stephen King and Peter Straub. (Viking, $18.95.) Two parallel
worlds and a young boy who can travel between them.
THE LIFE AND HARD TIMES OF HEIDI ABROMOWITZ, by Joan Rivers.
(Delacorte, $8.95.) The comedienne tells the ''true story'' of her high school
''friend,'' a notorious tramp.
VIRGIN AND MARTYR, by Andrew M. Greeley. (Bernard Geis/Warner, $17.50.)
The life of a Chicago-born nun who comes to a horrendous end in Central
America, told as a parable.
HOTEL DU LAC, by Anita Brookner. (Pantheon, $13.95.) An unmarried female
novelist on vacation discovers a solitary life can be worth living.

Non-Fiction
IACOCCA: An Autobiography, by Lee Iacocca with William Novak. (Bantam,
$19.95.) The rise of the automobile executive from immigrants' son to top jobs at
Ford and Chrysler.
BREAKING WITH MOSCOW, by Arkady N. Shevchenko. (Knopf, $18.95.) The
autobiography of the highest ranking Soviet official ever to defect.
LOVING EACH OTHER, by Leo Buscaglia. (Slack/Holt Rinehart & Winston,
$13.95.) Suggestions for ''setting our priorities right in order to enjoy life to the
fullest.''
CITIZEN HUGHES, by Michael Drosnin. (Holt, Rinehart & Winston, $18.95.)
Howard Hughes's attempts to control the Government during his last years of life.
SON OF THE MORNING STAR, By Evan S. Connell. (North Point Press, $20.) A
biography of George Armstrong Custer that is also a history of the Plains Indian
wars.
THE BRIDGE ACROSS FOREVER, by Richard Bach. (Morrow, $16.95.) The
author of ''Jonathan Livingston Seagull'' tells of his search for a true love.
THE LIVING PLANET, by David Attenborough. (Little, Brown, $25.) The land and
waters of our earth and the creatures that call them home; companion to the PBS
television series.
''SURELY YOU'RE JOKING, MR. FEYNMANN,'' by Richard P. Reynmann.
(Norton, $15.95.) a Nobel laureate in physics recounts his curious misadventures
inside and outside his profession.
THE SEVEN MOUNTAINS OF THOMAS MERTON, by Michael Mott. (Houghton
Mifflin, $24.95.) The life of the American religious writer and poet.
THE COURAGE TO CHANGE, by Dennis Wholey. (Houghton Mifflin, $15.95.)
Conversations with two dozen men and women, many of them celebrities, about
their problems with alcoholism.
MOSES THE KITTEN, by James Herriot. (St. Martin's, $9.95.) A waif kitten is
adopted by a pig; illustrated.
A LIGHT IN THE ATTIC, by Shell Silverstein. (Harper & Row, $13.50.) Light verse
and drawings by the author.
CRY OF THE KALAHARI, by Mark and Delia Owen. (Houghton Mifflin, $19.95.) A
young couple's experience living seven years in a southern African desert.
THE ABANDONMENT OF THE JEWS, by David S. Wyman. (Pantheon, $19.95.)
America's failure to attempt to save European Jews, 1941-45.
